Nanchang, China. 999 Xuefu Ave Honggutan District Nanchang China Graphical abstract The conversion of biomass-derived levulinic acid (LA) into 2-butanol offers a promising route to produce valuable secondary alcohols under sustainable conditions. In this study, a series of Ru-LaMnOx catalysts with varied Ru loadings were synthesized and their structural, electronic, and acidic properties were systematically characterized. Increasing Ru loading enhanced the surface Ru0/Ru4+ ratio and promoted the reduction of Mn species. These modifications led to an increased concentration of surface oxygen vacancies (Ov) and a higher density of Lewis acid sites, both of which are critical for the Meerwein–Ponndorf–Verley (MPV) reduction and subsequent hydrogenolysis of LA. Catalytic performance tests revealed that the optimized Ru3LaMnOx catalyst achieved a 2-butanol yield of 99.1 % at 200 °C under 5 MPa H2 and 8 h, along with good recyclability. This study identified the ring-opening of γ-valerolactone as the rate-determining step, with Ru0 sites and adjacent Ov facilitating hydrogen transfer and selective C–C bond cleavage. Density functional theory calculations confirmed that surface Ov enhanced LA and isopropanol adsorption and promote essential electron transfer processes. These findings demonstrate that tuning Ru loading to synergistically control electronic and acidic properties is a promising strategy for efficient biomass conversion. Keywords Ru-LaMnOx Biomass Surface oxygen vacancy Hydrogenolysis Secondary monoalcohol Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction The sustainable conversion of biomass into value-added chemicals is a pivotal challenge in modern catalysis, offering a promising route to reduce dependence on fossil fuels [1–3]. Despite various chemicals can be synthesized from biomass, the production of secondary monoalcohols remains particularly challenging. Recently, two approaches have been proposed to address this issue: selective primary C–O hydrogenolysis of polyols and the selective hydrogenolysis of levulinic acid (LA) and levulinates [4–6]. This study focuses on the latter, specifically targeting the hydrogenolysis of LA to produce the secondary alcohol 2-butanol, a compound with versatile applications as a solvent, fuel additive, and chemical intermediate [7]. The transformation of LA to 2-butanol involves a series of sequential reactions: LA is first converted to γ-valerolactone (GVL) via lactonization, followed by the ring-opening of GVL to form 5-hydroxy-2-pentanone (HPO). Subsequent hydrogenation of HPO yields 1,4-pentanediol (1,4-PDO), and finally, selective C–C bond cleavage of 1,4-PDO produces 2-butanol [8]. These steps require a metal–acid bifunctional catalyst that is capable of simultaneously activating hydrogen, facilitating hydrogen transfer, and promoting selective bond cleavage. Table S1 summarizes catalytic conversion of LA to 2-butanol. Ru and Ni-based catalysts are recently employed for LA hydrogenolysis to 2-butanol. While Ni-based catalysts, such as 15 %Ni-15 %Mn/Al2O3, have achieved respectable 2-butanol yields (∼84.5 %) under the conditions of 250 °C, 5 MPa H2, and 5 h in a isopropanol solvent [8], Ru-based catalysts, with lower metal loadings, have demonstrated superior performance under milder conditions. Notably, catalysts such as Ru-MnOx/Al2O3, Ru/C, Ru/C-TiO2, and Ru/CeO2 have been developed for production of 2-butanol from LA or GVL [6,9–12]. Among these Ru-based catalysts, Ru3.75Mn15/Al2O3 exhibited an exceptional 2-butanol yield of 98.8 % and turnover frequency number under the conditions of 200 °C, 5 MPa H2, and 4 h, due to its high concentrations of Ru0 and Mn2+, abundant surface oxygen vacancy (Ov), and Lewis acid sites [6]. Despite these advancements, the precise interplay among surface Ov, Lewis acid sites, and the surface concentration of Ru0 remains largely unexplored. Understanding these relationships is crucial for designing catalysts that maximize hydrogenolysis activity. In this context, Ru-loaded LaMnOx catalysts offer a unique platform where the metal-support interaction, oxygen vacancies (Ov), and acid sites can be finely tuned to enhance catalytic performance. The incorporation of Ru not only influences the textural properties of Ru-LaMnOx catalysts but also modulates their electronic structures, leading to an increased presence of surface Ru0 species, enhancing a higher reduction state of Mn species, and promoting the formation of surface Ov. These features are critical as surface Ov have been linked to enhanced Lewis acidity, which in turn facilitates key reaction steps in LA hydrogenolysis. In this study, a series of Ru-LaMnOx catalysts with varying Ru loadings were synthesized and comprehensively characterized. Higher Ru loadings were found to significantly increase the surface Ru⁰/Ru4+ ratio and promoted the reduction of surface Mn species. These modifications correlate with an elevated concentration of surface Ov and enhanced Lewis acid site density, which together facilitate the Meerwein–Ponndorf–Verley (MPV) reduction and subsequent hydrogenolysis of LA, ultimately leading to higher 2-butanol yields. Kinetic studies and in situ Diffuse Reflectance Infrared Fourier Transform Spectroscopy(DRIFTS) analyses provided insights into the reaction mechanism, highlighting that the ring-opening of GVL is the rate-determining step, while surface Ru cluster sites and adjacent Ov accelerate the crucial hydrogen transfer and bond-cleavage processes. Density functional theory (DFT) calculations further supported these experimental findings, demonstrating that surface Ov not only enhanced the adsorption of LA and isopropanol (IPA) but also promoted electron transfer processes essential for LA hydrogenolysis reactions. Collectively, this work demonstrates that optimizing Ru loading on LaMnOx catalysts enhances catalytic performance by synergistically tuning surface Ov, electronic, and acidic properties, thereby providing a promising strategy for the efficient conversion of LA to 2-butanol. 2 Experimental 2.1 Materials and preparation of catalyst La(NO3)3·6H2O) (99 %), Mn(NO3)3 (50 wt% in H2O), NH3·H2O (25–28 %), RuCl3·xH2O, methanol (MeOH, 99.5 %), ethanol (EtOH, 99.7 %), 1,4-dioxane (99.7 %), IPA (99.5 %), acetone (99.5 %), 2-butanol (2-BuOH, 99 %), 2-pentanol (2-PeOH, 98 %),HPO (95 %),1,4-PDO (98 %), GVL (98 %), LA (99 %), methyl levulinate (ML, 98 %), ethyl levulinate (EL, 99 %), propyl levulinate (PL, 98 %), and butyl levulinate (BL, 98 %) were purchased from Macklin Inc. and used without further purification. LaMnOx was prepared via a citric acid sol–gel method [13,14]. Briefly, 0.02 mol each of La(NO3)3·6H2O and Mn(NO3)3 were dissolved in 95.4 mL distilled water, followed by the slow addition of 0.08 mol citric acid monohydrate. The pH was adjusted to 8.0 using NH3·H2O, and the solution was stirred at 95 °C until a gel was formed. The gel was dried at 110 °C for 48 h, then heat-treated at 400 °C for 3 h (5 °C/min) to remove residual citric acid. Finally, calcination at 700 °C for 3 h yielded LaMnOx support. Ru-LaMnOx catalysts were prepared by wet impregnation. Specifically, 0.97 g of LaMnOx was placed in a beaker, and a RuCl3·H2O solution was slowly added while stirring at 100 °C. The resulting powder was dried at 100 °C, calcined at 300 °C for 2 h, and then reduced in a hydrogen atmosphere at 400 °C for 5 h to obtain the catalyst. By varying the amounts of LaMnOx and RuCl3·H2O, catalysts with different loadings (RuyLaMnOx, y = 3, 2, and 0.5) were synthesized. 2.2 Catalyst characterizations, testing, and product analysis Details on catalyst characterizations, including X-ray diffraction (XRD), N2 sorption, scanning electron microscope (SEM), Transmission Electron Microscope (TEM), inductively coupled plasma optical emission spectroscopy (ICP-OES), X-ray photoelectron spectra (XPS), Thermal gravimetric analysis and differential thermal gravimetric analysis (TG/DTG), Electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR), Pyridine Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy (Py-FTIR), and in situ DRIFTS are given in Supplementary material. Catalyst testing (using a four-station parallel reactor from Guizhou Shanli Experimental Instrument Co., Ltd), product analysis, and calculations of reaction kinetics and apparent activation energy are presented in Supplementary material. 2.3 Density functional theory calculations Three simplified slabs with LaMnO3(3 1 1 ¯ ) support and Ru6 cluster or Ru single atom were set up, i.e., RuNP-LaMnOx with perfect surface (110 atoms, Ru6La24Mn24O56), RuNP-LaMnOx with adjacent Ov (109 atoms, Ru6La24Mn24O55), and RuSAC-LaMnOx with adjacent Ov (104 atoms, Ru1 La24Mn24O55). The bottom layer of LaMnO3 was frozen, while rest were relaxed, and a vacuum layer of 18 Å was set to prevent interactions between periodic images in Z-directions. Other details on density functional theory (DFT) calculations are given in Supplementary material. 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Textural properties of Ru-LaMnOx The textural properties of the Ru-LaMnOx catalysts were characterized using XRD, N2 sorption, SEM, and TEM (Fig. 1 ). The XRD pattern displayed typical features of LaMnO3, with a dominant peak at 2θ = 32.6°, corresponding to the (3 1 1 ¯ ) facet (PDF#33-0713) [13]. No distinct peak for Ru was observed, likely due to the high dispersion of Ru on the support (Fig. 1a) [15], confirmed by elemental mapping snapshots (Fig. 1g). Despite the absence of Ru peaks in the XRD, ICP-OES analysis (Table S2) and elemental mapping confirmed successful Ru loading. TEM images (Fig. 1k–m) further indicated the presence of LaMnO3 and Ru compositions, with distinct fringe spaces for LaMnO3(3 1 1 ¯ ), Ru(1 0 1), and RuO2(1 1 1) [13,16]. N2 sorption isotherms and pore size distribution curves (Fig. 1b and c) revealed differences in the catalysts, all of which exhibited type IV isotherms. The Ru0.5LaMnOx catalyst showed similar isotherms and pore distributions to the LaMnOx support, with a high BET surface area of ∼140 m2/g, a pore volume of ∼0.4 cm3/g, and a pore size of ∼11.8 nm. However, as the Ru loading increased, the Ru2LaMnOx and Ru3LaMnOx catalysts exhibited lower BET surface areas, pore volumes, and pore sizes. This suggests that higher Ru loadings may lead to distinct textual properties. These results highlight the influence of Ru loading on the catalyst's textural properties, where Ru cluster size and metal-support interactions probably contribute to catalytic performance differences [17]. 3.2 Effect of Ru loading on electronic properties XPS analysis was conducted to examine the electronic properties of surface metals, which directly interact with reactants and intermediates (Figs. 2 and S1). The Ru 3p spectrum (Fig. 2a) displays peaks at 462.17 eV and 465.91 eV, corresponding to the Ru 3p3/2 states of Ru0 and Ru4+, respectively [18]. Additional peaks at 484.43 eV and 487.70 eV represent the Ru 3p1/2 states of Ru0 and Ru4+. As Ru loading increases, the Ru0 content rises while the Ru4+ content declines (Table S3). The Ru0/Ru4+ ratio follows the order: Ru3LaMnOx (3.24) > Ru2LaMnOx (2.58) > Ru0.5LaMnOx (2.38) (Fig. 2d). The Mn 2p spectrum (Fig. 2b) reveals peaks at 641.2 eV and 642.7 eV, assigned to Mn2+ and Mn3+ in the Mn 2p3/2 state [6]. The presence of satellite peaks confirms Mn2+ in all LaMnOx based catalysts. As shown in Fig. 2e–f and Table S3, higher Ru loading leads to an increase in Mn2+ content while Mn3+ decreases. The Mn 3s spectrum (Fig. 2c) was used to calculate the average oxidation state (AOS) based on ΔE values (Table S3) [19]. The AOS follows the order: Ru3LaMnOx (2.20) < Ru2LaMnOx (2.70) < Ru0.5LaMnOx (3.24) < LaMnOx (3.42). This observation was probably due to the electron transfer from Ru species to Mn species and hydrogen spillover from Ru to Mn species, resulting in Mn species reduction and Mn2+ content increase [20,21]. These results suggest that increasing Ru loading enhances the surface concentration of Ru0 and Mn2+ while reducing Mn3+. This suggests that a higher Ru0 content improves hydrogenation activity, facilitating reduction reactions such as hydrogenolysis of LA and intermediates [22]. Meanwhile, the increase in Mn2+ and decrease in Mn3+ indicate that Ru loading promotes Mn species reduction, probably generating more Ov at the Ru cluster-LaMnOx interface, which may further influence catalytic performance through facilitating the adsorption of LA or IPA. 3.3 Effect of Ru loading on oxygen vacancy Surface Ov plays a crucial role in determining the acidic properties and adsorption capacity of catalysts, thereby influencing reduction and oxidation reactions. In this study, XPS O 1s and electron paramagnetic resonance (EPR) analyses were conducted to evaluate Ov in Ru-LaMnOx catalysts (Fig. 3 a and b). The O 1s XPS spectra (Fig. 3a) showed two peaks at ∼529.5 eV and 531.1 eV, corresponding to lattice oxygen (Olatt) and adsorbed oxygen (Oads), respectively. While Olatt is relatively immobile, Oads is associated with surface Ov [23]. The Oads/Olatt ratio serves as an indicator of surface Ov content, with values following the trend: Ru3LaMnOx (8.99) > Ru2LaMnOx (4.17) > Ru0.5LaMnOx (2.10) > LaMnOx (1.83) (Table S3). These results highlight that a high loading of Ru on LaMnOx support facilitated the formation of surface Ov. Surface Ov has been proved showing high activity in MPV reduction of LA, facilitating production of GVL from LA [24]. Therefore, the Ru3LaMnOx with highest Ru loading probably exhibit the highest activity in MPV reduction of LA, further increasing the production of 2-butanol from LA hydrogenolysis. EPR measurements, which detect both surface and bulk Ov [25], showed a different trend (spins/g): Ru3LaMnOx (2.350 × 1013) < Ru2LaMnOx (2.938 × 1013) < Ru0.5LaMnOx (3.491 × 1013) (Fig. 3b). Unlike XPS, EPR indicates that Ru0.5LaMnOx has the highest concentration of Ov probably due to its abundant bulk Ov. However, since bulk Ov ​does not directly interact with surface reactants, its influence on MPV reduction and LA hydrogenolysis was limited. 3.4 Effect of Ru loading on Lewis acid sites The nature and quantity of surface acid sites play a crucial role in LA hydrogenolysis. In Mn-based catalysts, Lewis acid sites have been shown to facilitate both MPV reduction of LA and levulinates to GVL and the hydrogenolysis of LA to 2-butanol [6,24]. To distinguish between Lewis and Brønsted acid sites on the catalyst surface, Py-FTIR analysis was conducted (Fig. 3c). Peaks at 1450 cm−1 and 1615 cm−1 correspond to pyridine adsorption on Lewis acid sites, while the band at 1490 cm−1 is attributed to hybrid acid sites [26]. The results showed that all Ru-LaMnOx catalysts predominantly contain Lewis acid sites with minimal Brønsted acidity. Moreover, Lewis acid content increases with higher Ru loading. This trend is attributed to different metal-support interaction between Ru and LaMnOx species. As indicated by above analysis, higher Ru loading on LaMnOx facilitated the reduction of support species, creating increased surface Ov concentration which has been suggested as an important type of Lewis acid [27–29]. This observation was further supported by correlation analysis between surface Ov and Lewis acid amount (Fig. 3d), which revealed a positive linear relationship, indicating that surface Ov in Ru-LaMnOx contributes to the formation of Lewis acid sites. Surface Ov and Lewis acid can be derived from partial reduction of Mn species, as indicated by the positive correlation between surface Mn2+ fraction and the Lewis/ Brønsted ratio (Fig. S2). Additionally, the Ru0/Ru4+ ratio also exhibited a similar positive correlation with Lewis acid content (Fig. 3e), emphasizing the crucial role of Ru0 in promoting the reduction of Mn species, and the formation of surface Ov and Lewis acid. The significance of Ru0, surface Ov, and Lewis acid sits in LA hydrogenolysis to 2-butanol was further confirmed by following catalytic performance tests and the linear positive correlation between 2-butanol yield and Lewis acid amounts (Fig. 3f). 3.5 Catalyst performance The characterization results revealed that variations in Ru loading led to significant differences in surface composition and acidity of the Ru-LaMnOx catalysts, which strongly influenced the hydrogenolysis of LA to 2-butanol. The catalytic performance of Ru-LaMnOx was evaluated under conditions of 200 °C, 8 h, and 5 MPa H2 (Figs. 4 and S3). Fig. 4a illustrates the product distribution for LA hydrogenolysis over different catalysts. In the absence of Ru, MnOx, LaOx, and LaMnOx primarily produced GVL, with small amounts of i-PL, HPO, and 1,4-PDO, and no detectable 2-butanol. With increasing Ru loading, the 2-butanol yield improved from 3.8 % for Ru0.5LaMnOx to 99.1 % for Ru3LaMnOx catalyst, which featured highest Ru0/Ru4+ ratio, surface Ov, and Lewis acid amounts. These results underscore the critical role of high Ru loading in achieving efficient LA hydrogenolysis to 2-butanol. In comparison with Ru-LaMnOx, Ru-CeOx and Ru-TiOx catalysts showed lower activity for 2-butanol yield (<18 %) from LA hydrogenolysis under identical conditions. The effects of reduction temperature and reaction temperature for Ru3LaMnOx were further investigated, with optimal conditions identified as a reduction temperature of 400 °C and a reaction temperature of 200 °C (Fig. S3a and b). Both lower and higher temperatures led to decreased 2-butanol yields. Additionally, various solvents, including H2O, 1,4-dioxane, methanol, ethanol, and IPA, were tested, with IPA proving to be the most effective for 2-butanol production, likely due to its superior hydrogen-donating capability (Fig. S3c). H2 pressure studies revealed that increasing H2 pressure facilitated LA hydrogenolysis, with the highest 2-butanol yield of 99.1 % achieved at 5 MPa H2 (Fig. S3d). LA hydrogenolysis to 2-butanol involves intermediates of GVL, HPO, and 1,4-PDO. Hydrogenolysis of these intermediates was also performed over different Ru-LaMnOx catalysts (Fig. 4b). Ru3LaMnOx exhibited the highest catalytic activity, yielding over 82.6 % 2-butanol with turnover numbers (TONs) exceeding 78. In contrast, Ru0.5LaMnOx showed the lowest 2-butanol yields (<6.8 %) and TONs (<39). The primary byproduct for Ru2LaMnOx and Ru0.5LaMnOx was GVL, highlighting the crucial role of GVL conversion in achieving high 2-butanol yields from LA hydrogenolysis. Product evolution experiments further supported this observation (Fig. 4c–e). While LA was rapidly consumed in all three catalysts, GVL conversion exhibited a rate order of Ru3LaMnOx > Ru2LaMnOx > Ru0.5LaMnOx, suggesting that GVL hydrogenolysis represents the rate-determining step in this reaction. Similarly, 2-butanol formed rapidly over Ru3LaMnOx but more slowly over Ru2LaMnOx and Ru0.5LaMnOx. Beyond its high activity in LA hydrogenolysis, Ru3LaMnOx demonstrated broad applicability in the hydrogenolysis of levulinates (methyl levulinate, ethyl levulinate, propyl levulinate, and butyl levulinate) to 2-butanol, achieving yields exceeding 88.5 % (Fig. 4f). 3.6 Recyclability The recyclability of Ru3LaMnOx was investigated for GVL hydrogenolysis, as LA exhibited rapid conversion. The catalyst demonstrated satisfactory stability over four consecutive cycles, with only a slight activity loss. The selectivity for 2-butanol remained above 80 %, while GVL conversion exceeded 95 %, and the turnover number (TON) remained above 72 (Fig. 5 a). To understand the causes of activity decline, comprehensive characterizations, including ICP-OES, XPS, TG-DTG, and SEM, were conducted. ICP-OES analysis confirmed that no detectable Ru leaching occurred in the reaction solution, indicating the stability of Ru species. SEM images before and after the reaction cycles revealed no significant structural changes in the catalyst (Fig. 5b). However, thermogravimetric analysis (TG-DTG) showed weight loss at approximately 335 °C, suggesting the presence of adsorbed impurities on the catalyst surface (Fig. 5c-d) [24,30]. Additionally, XPS analysis indicated increases in Mn2+ and Oads (Ov), probably resulting from the in situ reduction of the support during reaction cycles (Fig. S4). Meanwhile, the Ru0/Ru4+ ratio exhibited only a slight change (Table S3). While the spent catalyst demonstrated high Ov and Ru0 content, the presence of adsorbed impurities may have contributed to the minor activity loss observed in GVL hydrogenolysis to 2-butanol. Therefore, it should be noted that these changes may affect the long-term performance. Overall, Ru3LaMnOx exhibited good recyclability, and further efforts to prevent impurity adsorption and enhance the stability of the support are essential for maximizing its long-term catalytic performance and efficiency. 3.7 Reaction kinetics and mechanism To gain deeper insight into the influence of Ru loading on hydrogenolysis activity, in situ DRFITS analysis was performed to investigate the interaction/reaction between catalysts (LaMnOx and Ru3LaMnOx) and 1,4-PDO or IPA. The removal of the CH2OH group from 1,4-PDO and the hydrogen transfer from IPA are both critical steps in LA hydrogenolysis to 2-butanol [6,31]. Fig. 6 a–c presents in situ DRIFTS results for 1,4-PDO interaction/reaction with catalyst. For LaMnOx, the intensity of the v(OH) vibration initially increases and then decreases as the contact time with the substrate increases. The maximum v(OH) intensities appear at 3890 and 3736 cm−1 [32] after 1 min, while the intensities of v(CH3) at 1428 and 1225 cm−1 gradually increase [33]. These variations indicate that 1,4-PDO is being adsorbed onto LaMnOx. Additionally, the emergence of peak at 2322 cm−1 (v(CC)) suggests that LaMnOx facilitates the dehydration of 1,4-PDO (Fig. 6a). In contrast, the in situ DRIFTS results for Ru3LaMnOx interaction/reaction with 1,4-PDO show negligible changes for v(OH) groups (Fig. 6b). The signals at 1544 cm−1 (v(C–C)) and 1434 cm−1 (v(CH3)) increased over time, highlighting the strong interaction/reaction between C–C bond with Ru3LaMnOx, probably facilitating the C–C bond breakage of 1,4-PDO to remove CH2OH group. The final states of two catalysts, as shown in Fig. 6c, show significant differences for their interaction/reaction with 1,4-PDO. The presence of Ru markedly suppresses dehydration, as evidenced by the near disappearance of the transition state at 2322 cm−1 (v(CC)), while promoting C–C bond cleavage, as indicated by the increased intensities at 1544 cm−1 (v(C–C)) and 1434 cm−1 (v(CH3)) [33]. These findings highlight Ru’s role in shifting the reaction pathway toward selective C–C bond cleavage, thereby enhancing 2-butanol production. The in situ DRIFTS analysis of catalyst-IPA interaction/reaction examines the hydrogen transfer activity of catalysts (Fig. 6d–f). For LaMnOx, both v(CH3) and v(OH) intensities gradually increase with contact time, indicating strong isopropanol adsorption (Fig. 6d). A slight increase in the v(CO) signal at 1642 cm−1 suggests limited dehydrogenation activity of IPA over LaMnOx. In contrast, an inverted peak at 3428 cm−1 (v(OH)) and a higher intensity of signal at 1642 cm−1 (v(CO)) was observed for Ru3LaMnOx-IPA interaction/reaction (Fig. 6e), indicating conversion of IPA to acetone over Ru3LaMnOx. The comparison of the final states shows distinct differences for the interaction/reaction of catalyst-IPA (Fig. 6f). While LaMnOx primarily promotes IPA adsorption and accumulation, Ru3LaMnOx facilitates its rapid conversion, highlighting an enhanced hydrogen transfer capability of Ru3LaMnOx catalyst [34]. Additionally, the reaction kinetics of GVL and 1,4-PDO hydrogenolysis over Ru3LaMnOx were investigated, as both are considered key steps in LA hydrogenolysis to 2-butanol (Fig. 4c–e). Apparent activation energies of 40.98 kJ/mol for GVL hydrogenolysis and 29 kJ/mol for 1,4-PDO hydrogenolysis were observed (Fig. 6g–i). Together with the slow conversion rate of GVL (Fig. 4c–e) and low H2 reaction order for GVL, this finding further confirms that the ring-opening of GVL is the rate-determining step in the overall LA hydrogenolysis pathway to 2-butanol due to high stability of GVL, consistent with previous studies on LA hydrogenolysis [35,36]. Fig. 6i presents the reaction orders of H2 for GVL (0.07), HPO (0.41), and 1,4-PDO (0.13) conversion over Ru3LaMnOx. The lower reaction orders of H2 for GVL and 1,4-PDO suggest that the initial steps, GVL ring-opening and C–C bond cleavage of 1,4-PDO, are H2-independent or proceed at a slower rate. In contrast, the higher reaction order for HPO conversion indicates a more rapid hydrogenation step. Collectively, a plausible reaction mechanism for LA hydrogenolysis to 2-butanol is proposed, in which the ring-opening of GVL represents the slow step, while rest steps proceed more rapidly (Fig. 6j). 3.8 DFT calculations DFT calculations were performed to gain molecular level insights into the high activity of Ru-LaMnOx catalyst (Fig. 7 ). The role of surface oxygen vacancies (Ov) was first examined. A RuNP-LaMnOx slab with an adjacent surface Ov exhibited stronger adsorption affinities for both LA and IPA, with adsorption energies of −1.84 eV and −1.21 eV, respectively. In this configuration, both LA and IPA preferentially adsorbed onto the surface Ov (Fig. 7a). In contrast, the RuNP-LaMnOx slab without surface Ov showed weaker adsorption energies of −1.41 eV for LA and −0.42 eV for IPA, with both molecules adsorbing on the Ru cluster instead. Bader charge analysis further revealed that LA gained more electrons from the surface Ov than from the Ru cluster (1.9 vs. 1.45 electrons), indicating a stronger tendency for reduction reactions in the presence of surface Ov (Fig. 7c). Conversely, IPA gained fewer electrons from surface Ov than from the Ru cluster (0.85 vs. 0.97 electrons), suggesting a greater tendency for IPA dehydrogenation on Ru sites. These observations indicate that RuNP-LaMnOx with surface Ov is more effective in facilitating LA hydrogenolysis. On the other hand, the effect of Ru cluster size on H2 activation was explored, given that Ru metal is primarily responsible for H2 activation [37,38]. The RuNP-LaMnOx catalyst with surface Ov exhibited homolytic H2 adsorption with an energy of −1.34 eV, higher than that of H2 adsorption on single atom catalyst (SAC) RuSAC-LaMnOx with surface Ov. This result highlights the superior H2 activation ability of Ru clusters compared to Ru single-atom catalysts. GVL also showed favorable adsorption on RuNP-LaMnOx with surface Ov compared to that without surface Ov (−2.58 eV vs. −1.19 eV). Furthermore, the ring-opening reaction of GVL proceeds with a lower energy barrier on the catalyst with surface Ov (0.14 eV) than on the vacancy-free surface (0.70 eV), highlighting the crucial role of oxygen vacancies in facilitating the reaction. Collectively, RuNP-LaMnOx with adjacent surface Ov demonstrated higher activity in H2 activation, LA hydrogenolysis, and IPA dehydrogenation, underscoring the crucial role of surface Ov and Ru loading in enhancing the catalytic performance of Ru-LaMnOx for LA hydrogenolysis to 2-butanol. 4 Conclusions In this study, Ru-LaMnOx catalysts with varying Ru loadings were synthesized and systematically characterized to investigate their structural, electronic, and catalytic properties for LA hydrogenolysis to 2-butanol. Increasing Ru content significantly altered surface composition and electronic properties of Ru-LaMnOx catalysts, as evidenced by an enhanced Ru0/Ru4+ ratio and Mn2+ concentration. These changes promoted the formation of surface Ov and increased the density of Lewis acid sites, both of which are crucial for facilitating LA hydrogenolysis. Comprehensive analyses using XPS, EPR, and Py-FTIR confirmed these modifications. Catalytic tests revealed that the Ru3LaMnOx catalyst achieved a remarkable 2-butanol yield of 99.1 % under optimal conditions, with kinetic studies indicating that GVL ring-opening is the rate-determining step. Collectively, these findings with in situ DRIFTS and DFT studies underscore the synergistic effect of Ru loading, surface Ov, and Lewis acidity, offering a promising strategy for designing efficient biomass conversion catalysts. coredata.dc:description: The conversion of biomass-derived levulinic acid (LA) into 2-butanol offers a promising route to produce valuable secondary alcohols under sustainable conditions. In this study, a series of Ru-LaMnOx catalysts with varied Ru loadings were synthesized and their structural, electronic, and acidic properties were systematically characterized. Increasing Ru loading enhanced the surface Ru0/Ru4+ ratio and promoted the reduction of Mn species. These modifications led to an increased concentration of surface oxygen vacancies (Ov) and a higher density of Lewis acid sites, both of which are critical for the Meerwein–Ponndorf–Verley (MPV) reduction and subsequent hydrogenolysis of LA. Catalytic performance tests revealed that the optimized Ru3LaMnOx catalyst achieved a 2-butanol yield of 99.1 % at 200 °C under 5 MPa H2 and 8 h, along with good recyclability. This study identified the ring-opening of γ-valerolactone as the rate-determining step, with Ru0 sites and adjacent Ov facilitating hydrogen transfer and selective C–C bond cleavage. Density functional theory calculations confirmed that surface Ov enhanced LA and isopropanol adsorption and promote essential electron transfer processes. These findings demonstrate that tuning Ru loading to synergistically control electronic and acidic properties is a promising strategy for efficient biomass conversion.
